questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is (substance) inert/ unreactive?
correct: Full valence electron shell of 2/8 electrons, hence will not lose, gain or share electrons to be bonded with chlorine.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is (substance) a non-metal?
correct: Have a tendency to attract electrons to achieve noble gas stable electronic configuration

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why do larger molecules have higher melting/boiling point?
correct: Larger molecules have stronger intermolecular forces between the molecules
More energy required to overcome the stronger intermolecular forces of attraction

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is (substance) the limiting reactant in a reaction?
correct: _ mole of (state specific reactant) needs _ mole of (state specific substance) to fully react, but there is only __ mole of (specific substance)

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is _ a weak acid?
correct: It undergoes partial dissociation in water to produce a low concentration of H+ ions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is _ a strong acid?
correct: It undergoes complete dissociation in water to produce a high concentration of H+ ions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is _ a weak alkali?
correct: It undergoes partial dissociation in water to produce a low concentration of OH- ions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is _ a strong alkali?
correct: It undergoes complete dissociation in water to produce a high concentration of OH- ions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is Aluminium(metal) oxide basic??
correct: Aluminium(metal) oxide is basic as Aluminium(metal) is a metallic element

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is Silicon(non-metal) dioxide acidic??
correct: Silicon(non-metal) oxide is acidic as Silicon(non-metal) is a non-metallic element

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain why the pH of the solution increases as an acid is added?
correct: Increases concentration of H+ ions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain why the pH of the solution increases as an alkali is added?
correct: Increases concentration of OH- ions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Copper (II) carbonate thermally decomposed at a faster rate than calcium carbonate. Explain?
correct: Copper is a less reactive metal than calcium metal
Thus, copper forms a less stable metal carbonate and would hence, decompose at a faster rate

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: How sacrificial protection with a magnesium block helps to prevent the rusting of iron?
correct: As Magnesium is more reactive than iron, it will lose electrons/ gets oxidised, and corrode preferentially over iron

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: In the electrolysis of dilute aqueous sodium chloride(or other hallide) using inert electrodes, explain why chlorine gas (halogen gas) is not formed at the anode?
correct: Hydroxide ions are discharged in preference over the chloride(halogen) ions at the anode

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: In the electrolysis of concentrated aqueous sodium chloride(or other hallide) using inert electrodes, explain why a yellowish-green gas (halogen gas) is formed at the anode?
correct: Chloride(halogen)ions are discharged in preference over the hydroxide ions at the anode as there is a higher concentration of chloride ions, forming chlorine gas which is yellowish-green

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: In the electrolysis of dilute aqueous sodium (more reactive metal) salt using inert electrodes, explain why is there effervescence at the cathode?
correct: As sodium (more reactive metal) is more reactive than hydrogen, hydrogen ions are discharged in preference over the sodium ions at the cathode, forming hydrogen gas and hence causing effervescence

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: In the electrolysis of dilute aqueous copper(II) (less reactive metal)  salt using inert electrodes, explain why a reddish-brown solid is formed at the cathode?
correct: As hydrogen is more reactive than copper (less reactive metal), copper(II) (less reactive metal) ions are discharged in preference over the hydrogen ions at the cathode, forming copper solid, which is reddish-brown

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: In the electrolysis of aqueous copper(II) sulfate using copper electrodes, explain why the concentration of copper(II) sulfate remains constant during the experiment?
correct: For every 1 mole of CU oxidised to form Cu2+ at the anode, there is 1 mole of Cu2+ reduced at the cathode to form Cu
Thus, there is no net change in the concentration of copper(II) ions in the solution

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is this reaction exothermic??
correct: The total energy taken in to break bond in (state specific reactant) is less than
Total energy given out to form bonds in (state specific product)

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why is this reaction endothermic??
correct: The total energy taken in to break bond in (state specific reactant) is greater than
Total energy given out to form bonds in (state specific product)

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: How increase in temperature increases speed of reaction?
correct: Higher temperature, more (state specific reacting particles) have energy equal to or greater than the activation energy
Higher frequency of effective collisions between (state specific reacting particles), shorter time taken for 1 complete reaction, faster speed of reactions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: How increase in amount increases speed of reaction?
correct: More reacting particles available for collision
Higher frequency of effective collisions between (state specific reacting particles), shorter time taken for 1 complete reaction, faster speed of reactions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: How increase in concentration/pressure increases speed of reaction?
correct: More particles per unit volume, reacting particles are closer together
Higher frequency of effective collisions between (state specific reacting particles), shorter time taken for 1 complete reaction, faster speed of reactions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: How decrease in particle size increases speed of reaction?
correct: Greater total exposed surface area for reacting particles to collide
Higher frequency of effective collisions between (state specific reacting particles), shorter time taken for 1 complete reaction, faster speed of reactions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: How catalysts affect rate of reaction?
correct: Increase speed of reaction by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation energy for the reaction. More colliding particles possess energy equal to or greater than activation energy
Higher frequency of effective collisions between (state specific reacting particles), shorter time taken for 1 complete reaction, faster speed of reactions

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why reversible reaction cannot reach 100%?
correct: Some of the (state product) will always react to form back the (state reactants)

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why would organic compounds be in the same homologous series?
correct: They have the same general formula of _ OR
They have similar chemical properties of _

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why are substances isomers??
correct: They both have the same number of atoms of the same elements (State how many atoms of each element), but the atoms are arranged and bonded differently

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain in terms of oxygen/hydrogen/electron transfer, why (substance) is oxidised?
correct: (State specific substance reactant) gained oxygen from/ donated hydrogen to/ donated an electron to (other reactant) to form (substance after reaction)

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain in terms of oxygen/hydrogen/electron transfer, why (substance) is reduced?
correct: (State specific substance reactant) lost oxygen to/ gain hydrogen from/ accepted an electron from (other reactant) to form (substance after reaction)

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain why this is a redox reaction?
correct: _ is oxidised as ...(oxygen gain/oxidation state increase/donated hydrogen/ donate electron) from _ to _
_ is reduced as ...(oxygen loss/oxidation state decrease/accepted hydrogen/ accepted electron) from _ to _. With both reduction and oxidation, this reaction is a redox reaction

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why (substance) is a reducing agent?
correct: (State specific substance reactant) gained oxygen from/ lost hydrogen to/ donated an electron to (other reactant), reducing _ to _

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Why (substance) is an oxidising agent?
correct: (State specific substance reactant) lost oxygen to/ gain hydrogen from/ accepted an electron from (other reactant), oxidising _ to _

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain in terms of oxidation state, why (substance) is oxidised?
correct: (State specific substance reactant) increased in oxidation state from _ in _ to _ in _

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: Explain in terms of oxidation state, why (substance) is reduced?
correct: (State specific substance reactant) decreased in oxidation state from _ in _ to _ in _
